docs.title: Welcome to MoE Exam System Documentation Hub
docs.text: Empowering education through technology, this platform—proudly sponsored by UNOPS—provides comprehensive guidance and support for educators, administrators, and developers working with student testing software in Ethiopia. It’s your gateway to creating, managing, and delivering effective digital assessments.

docs.title: Our Mission
docs.text: To transform education in Ethiopia by equipping schools and institutions with reliable and innovative software solutions for student testing and evaluation.

docs.title: What You'll Find Here
docs.text:
• User Guides: Step-by-step documentation to help you navigate the testing software efficiently.
  • Implementation Strategies: Tips and best practices to integrate the software into Ethiopian educational contexts.
  • Troubleshooting Resources: Solutions to common issues and advice for smooth operation.
  • Community Support: Connect with experts and peers to share knowledge and experiences.

docs.title: Why it Matters?
docs.text: Digital testing tools play a crucial role in enhancing learning outcomes and making evaluations more accessible and transparent. With Ethiopia’s focus on advancing education, this hub serves as a catalyst for modernization and academic excellence.

docs.title: Production Environment Requirements
docs.text:
The production environment resources are fully utilized during exam (peak) periods, while certain resources can be scaled down or decommissioned during idle times to optimize costs and efficiency.

docs.title: Dynamic Scaling of Moodle Application Servers:
docs.text: During peak periods, all 7 to 10 application servers per cluster will remain active to handle high user loads. During idle or non-peak times, application servers will be scaled down to 2 servers per cluster, reducing resource consumption while maintaining service availability.

docs.title: Leveraging Auto-Scaling Services:
docs.text: If Ethio-Telecom offers an auto-scaling service, it will be integrated with the Elastic Load Balancer (ELB) to dynamically allocate and decommission application servers based on real-time demand. In the absence of an auto-scaling feature, the scaling process will be managed manually or through orchestration tools like Ansible, ensuring efficient deallocation and decommissioning of resources.

docs.title: Resource Decommissioning:
docs.text: Excess Moodle application servers will be shut down and deallocated automatically or manually during non-peak times, leveraging Ansible for seamless scaling.

docs.title: Elastic Load Balancer and WAF Flexibility:
docs.text: The ELB will maintain load balancing with auto-failover capabilities, while WAF instances will scale to handle concurrent connections as needed.

docs.title: Caching and Database Services:
docs.text: Caching services and database instances will maintain consistent performance, with caching clusters scaled based on the active application server count.

docs.title: Ansible Server and Jump Server Utilization:
docs.text: The Ansible Server will manage configuration and deployment tasks, while the Jump Server will ensure secure administrative access, both running at minimal capacity during idle times. Outcome: This cost optimization strategy will enable the environment to dynamically adapt to workload changes, minimizing costs while maintaining performance and availability. The integration of Ethio-Telecom's auto-scaling service (if available) will further automate resource management, contributing to operational efficiency and reducing the total cost of ownership (TCO).
